online.common
Class StockArt

java.lang.Object
  online.common.StockArt
All Implemented Interfaces:
DrawableSprite
Direct Known Subclasses:
online.game.chip
public class StockArt
extends java.lang.Object
implements DrawableSprite

StockArt is a thin extension on Image, with support for loading, masking, scaling and displaying the images. A selection of useful images are loaded automatically, and your artwork can be loaded separately as stock art.

Most of the "chip" classes are subclasses of stockart.

The general characteristics of StockArt is that they are immutable, scalable images that are used by the program. Generally, one copy of the image is loaded into a static variable at initialization time, and used throughout the rest of the program.

Author:
ddyer

Field Detail

file

public java.lang.String file
the file from which this image was loaded

scale

public double[] scale
An array of 3 elements, x offset, y offset and scale factor.
These parameters are used to normalize the location and size of the image relative to its center. This array is normally set up during construction and not changed.

image

public java.awt.Image image
the underlying image for this StockArt

Method Detail

getScale

public double[] getScale()
get the scale factor array for this image, which is the normal x,y,scale to display the image. The neutral values would be {0.5,0.5,1.0}

These scale factors are normally hand-tuned so the default size and positioning of the artwork is as desired - the alternative to using these scale factors is to actually edit the image with photoshop.

Note that if you stay within the system, you'll never need to see or use these scale factors, they're just an internal detail you tune so the images look right.

Returns:
an array double[3]

getImage

public java.awt.Image getImage()
get the underlying image

drawChipFancyText

public void drawChipFancyText(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                              exCanvas canvas,
                              int SQUARESIZE,
                              int cx,
                              int cy,
                              java.lang.String label,
                              boolean artCenter)
draw the image (or it's alternate) and a text string to label it. The string is drawn centered according to the x,y offset. The image is drawn centered at the x,y specified, and scaled to fill the specified square size, as adjusted by the image's internal offset and scale factors.

Parameters:
gc - a graphics or null
canvas - the canvas to draw on
SQUARESIZE -
cx -
cy -
label - the string label, or null
artCenter - if true, draw text at teh artwork center rather than the image center.
See Also:
drawImage

drawChipImage

public void drawChipImage(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                          exCanvas canvas,
                          int cx,
                          int cy,
                          double[] pscale,
                          int SQUARESIZE,
                          double xscale,
                          double jitter,
                          java.lang.String label,
                          boolean artcenter)
this is the lowest level overridable method, which actually passes to the canvas for drawing. Stock art which constructs its image in complex ways can override this method. The standard definition of this method is canvas.drawImage(gc, getImage(), pscale,cx, cy, SQUARESIZE, xscale,yscale,label,artcenter);

canvas -
cx -
cy -
pscale -
SQUARESIZE -

drawChip

public boolean drawChip(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                        exCanvas drawOn,
                        int rackLocation,
                        HitPoint highlight,
                        int squareWidth,
                        int e_x,
                        int e_y,
                        java.lang.String thislabel)
draw a chip and test for mouse sensitivity. If the highlight is hit, the width is increased by 1/3 to give a visual "pop" to indicate the hit.

Parameters:
gc - // the graphics to draw with
drawOn - // the canvas to do the drawing
highlight - // the mouse point, or null. Receives hit information
squareWidth - // the overall scale of the object
e_x - // the center of the object
e_y - // the center y of the object
thislabel - // label to print on top
Returns:
true if this chip is hit

drawChip

public boolean drawChip(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                        exCanvas drawOn,
                        int rackLocation,
                        HitPoint highlight,
                        int squareWidth,
                        double scale,
                        int e_x,
                        int e_y,
                        java.lang.String thislabel)
draw a chip and test for mouse sensitivity. If the highlight is hit, the width is increased by 1/3 to give a visual "pop" to indicate the hit.

Parameters:
gc - // the graphics to draw with
drawOn - // the canvas to do the drawing
rackLocation - // the rack code for this location
highlight - // the mouse point, or null. Receives hit information
squareWidth - // the overall scale of the object
scale - // the percentage scale of the x axis (used to stretch or squish)
e_x - // the center of the object
e_y - // the center y of the object
thislabel - // label to print on top
Returns:
true if this chip is hit

findChipHighlight

public boolean findChipHighlight(int rackLocation,
                                 HitPoint highlight,
                                 int squareWidth,
                                 int squareHeight,
                                 int e_x,
                                 int e_y)
do highlight detection for drawChip(java.awt.Graphics, online.common.exCanvas, int, int, int, java.lang.String) and drawStack This uses pointInsideCell(online.common.HitPoint, int, int, int, int) to determine if the point is inside, and calls registerChipHit(int, online.common.HitPoint, int, int, int, int) to mark the hit in the highlight object.

Parameters:
highlight -
squareWidth -
e_x -
e_y -
Returns:
true if this is the first hit

pointInsideCell

public boolean pointInsideCell(HitPoint pt,
                               int x,
                               int y,
                               int SQW,
                               int SQH)
this method is made visible so you can tweak the radius that constitutes a hit. Note that the target is a smaller square, not a circle.

Parameters:
pt - the mouse location
x - x position of the chip
y - y position of the chip
SQW - square cell width of the chip
SQH - is the cell height of the chip
Returns:
true of point is inside the square centered at x,y
See Also:
drawChipHighlight, drawChip, drawStack

                               HitPoint highlight,

                               int e_y,
                               int e_w,
                               int e_h)
register a hit on this cell.

Parameters:
highlight -
e_x -
e_y -
Returns:
true if this is the hit object (even if not new)
